hints_html:
Notice that both the base and exponent of \(f(x)\) are functions of \(x\), so neither the power rule nor the exponential derivative rule will work here. What operation can you do to \(f(x)\) to express it as a product of functions?

Start by taking the logarithm of \(f\).
hints_latex:
Notice that both the base and exponent of $f(x)$ are functions of $x$,
so neither the power rule nor the exponential derivative rule will work
here. What operation can you do to $f(x)$ to express it as a product of
functions?
Start by taking the logarithm of $f$.
hints_raw:
Notice that both the base and exponent of <math>f(x)</math> are functions of <math>x</math>, so neither the power rule nor the exponential derivative rule will work here. What operation can you do to <math>f(x)</math> to express it as a product of functions?
Start by taking the logarithm of &fnof;.
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
Use logarithmic differentiation on this function.

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) &=(x+1)^{\cos(x)}\\ \ln(f(x)) &= \ln((x+1)^{\cos(x)})\\ &= \cos(x)\ln(x + 1)\end{aligned}\]

Taking the derivative of this equation with respect to \(x\) gives:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx}\left[\ln(f(x))\right] &= \frac{d}{dx}\left[\cos(x)\ln(x + 1)\right] \\ \frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} &= \frac{\cos(x)}{x + 1} - \sin(x)\ln(x+1) \\ f'(x) &= f(x)\left( \frac{\cos(x)}{x + 1} - \sin(x)\ln(x+1) \right)\\ {\color{blue}f'(x)} &{\color{blue}\,= (x+1)^{\cos(x)}\left( \frac{\cos(x)}{x + 1} - \sin(x)\ln(x+1) \right)}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Use logarithmic differentiation on this function.

:<math>
\begin{align}
f(x) &=(x+1)^{\cos(x)}\\
\ln(f(x)) &= \ln((x+1)^{\cos(x)})\\
&= \cos(x)\ln(x + 1)
\end{align}
</math>
Taking the derivative of this equation with respect to <math>x</math> gives:
:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{d}{dx}\left[\ln(f(x))\right] &= \frac{d}{dx}\left[\cos(x)\ln(x + 1)\right] \\
\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} &= \frac{\cos(x)}{x + 1} - \sin(x)\ln(x+1) \\
f'(x) &= f(x)\left( \frac{\cos(x)}{x + 1} - \sin(x)\ln(x+1) \right)\\
{\color{blue}f'(x)} &{\color{blue}\,= (x+1)^{\cos(x)}\left( \frac{\cos(x)}{x + 1} - \sin(x)\ln(x+1) \right)}
\end{align}
</math>
